Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Bringing Wireless Sensor Networks Underground

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
In this CAREER project, the development of wireless underground sensor networks, which carries information through soil, is investigated. More specifically, the application of underground networking in agriculture is considered, where underground sensor networks promise significant reduction in water usage for irrigation. The objectives of this project are to establish the foundations of underground networking for the realization of underground sensor networks, develop hands-on educational tools, and provide experiences to facilitate the dissemination of these techniques to a larger audience including students and farmers.

Communication performance in underground settings is significantly affected by the variations in soil conditions. Hence, the research activities are focused on revisiting the concepts of connectivity and interference under the influence of environmental factors such as soil composition, soil moisture, and depth. Moreover, a theoretical framework is developed to capture the spatial and temporal correlations in soil moisture for underground sensor networks, enabling the development of environment-aware communication protocols. The insights from these analyses are exploited to develop event-based cross-layer communication platforms that adapt to the environment in an energy efficient manner. Finally, an agricultural underground sensor network testbed is developed to evaluate and highlight the outcomes of this research. The educational components include bringing wireless sensor networking to the class, developing an interactive cyber-physical networking lab, and providing hands-on experiences for "little farmers".

The realization of the underground networking techniques has the potential to transform the agriculture industry, as well as a broad range of applications including border patrol, perimeter surveillance, and toxic material monitoring.

POR.DRECONTENT:
By 2050, World population is expected to reach 9.7 billion, doubling the need for food. Yet, cuttenrly, nearly 70% of all fresh water usage accounts for agricultural production. Thus, new technologies are needed to provide significant reductions in water usage for irrigation. The improvements in embedded system design and low-power wireless communication techniques have made wireless sensor networks an attractive tool for many application areas. In this project, the development of wireless underground sensor networks (WUSNs), which carries information through soil, is investigated. 

Despite their potential advantages, however, the realization of WUSNs is challenging due to the significant impact of soil characteristics on communication. The objectives of this project are to establish the foundations of underground networking for the realization of WUSNs, develop hands-on educational tools, and provide experiences to facilitate the dissemination of these techniques to K-12 students, undergraduate and graduate students as well as farmers.

This project has resulted in a novel ultra wideband underground antenna, which increases communication ranges by more than 370% compared to the original antennas, to 100-150m. This technology has been licensed and is being commercialized by the PI, with support from NSF I-Corps, SBIR, and Nebraska SBIR grants.

To establish foundations of underground networking, a closed-form channel model is developed based on three major components that influence underground communication: direct, reflected, and lateral waves. In addition, it is shown that soil moisture-adaptive forward error correction solutions can double the throughput compared to ARQ schemes because of a large number of packet losses (∼ 50%) due to very small number of bit errors (1.5) that can be corrected. In addition, the asymmetry in underground communication links is addressed through a soil-adaptive RTS/CTS scheme, which increase communication success from 32% to 76%.

The connectivity of WUSNs under varying environmental conditions is captured by modeling the cluster size distribution under sub-critical conditions and through a novel aboveground communication coverage model for underground clusters. It is shown that transmit power control can maintain network connectivity under all soil moisture values at the cost of energy consumption. Moreover, the feasibility of vibration energy harvesting for WUSNs is investigated based on an analytical framework to model the maximum harvestable power by a piezoelectric energy harvester at a certain depth. Field experiments illustrate the feasibility of vibration energy harvesting as a promising approach to be considered for the future underground sensor networks. Furthermore, by evaluating a family of mobile data harvesting protocols, it is shown that the network lifetime can be increased to 5 years. 

To investigate the foundations of wireless communications, the capacity of the underground channel is captured by modeling the antenna return loss, bandwidth, and propagation path loss, which become functions of soil characteristics in wireless underground communications. Experiment results and the analytical modeling reveal that a given antenna is matched to a different operation frequency as the soil moisture changes, which motivates the use of frequency-agile systems for capacity maximization in wireless underground communications. Accordingly, the use of cognitive radio systems, which can adjust operation frequency based on changes in soil properties, are explored.

To facilitate development of new communication techniques, underground channel impulse response is modeled and validated via extensive experiments in indoor and field testbed settings.This has resulted in the first empirical model for PHY layer parameters of underground communications. This will lead to tailor-made communication solutions for UG communications.

Furthermore, for the first time, this project has shown the feasibility of multi-carrier communication techniques in underground settings. A novel soil-adaptive system and sub-carrier bandwidth adaptation technique for UG multi-carrier communication is developed, which results in capacity gains of up to 136%. 

This project has supported extensive empirical evaluations to validate the developed models and techniques. To this end, the first indoor cognitive radio wireless underground communication testbed is implemented to measure the path loss and capacity at different distances and depths. This testbed provides flexible control over soil moisture and soil types. 

The accuracy and effectiveness of precision agriculture solutions are highly dependent on accurate and timely analysis of the soil conditions. In this project, an smart irrigation testbed is developed by integrating WUSNs with center pivot irrigation systems at the South Central Agriculture Laboratory of the University of Nebraska-Lincoln for precision agriculture. As a result, the first automated irrigation system aided by wireless underground sensors was developed.

Outcomes of the project have resulted in commercialization efforts through a start-up company, which has received NSF I-Corps, SBIR Phase I and Phase IB, and Nebraska SBIR matching funds for technology transfer. 

Throughout the project, fundamentals of wireless underground networks are disseminated to students through summer camps and courses. Farmers, crop consultants, agronomists are informed of developments through regularly scheduled workshops. Project results are published in premier conference and journals and the PI discussed the potential impacts of wireless networks in agriculture in various venues.
